div.p: the Rabbit asked.

quote.s: "I don't think it's at all a pity. I said\n'What for?'"
"The Queen will hear you! You see, she came rather late, and the\nQueen said--"
"Get to your places!"

div.p: shouted the Queen in a voice of thunder, and people began running about in all directions, tumbling up against each other; however, they got settled down in a minute or two, and the game began. Alice thought she had never seen such a curious croquet-ground in her life; it was all ridges and furrows; the balls were live hedgehogs, the mallets live flamingoes, and the soldiers had to double themselves up and to stand on their hands and feet, to make the arches.

The chief difficulty Alice found at first was in managing her flamingo: she succeeded in getting its body tucked away, comfortably enough, under her arm, with its legs hanging down, but generally, just as she had got its neck nicely straightened out, and was going to give the hedgehog a blow with its head, it _would_ twist itself round and look up in her face, with such a puzzled expression that she could not help bursting out laughing: and when she had got its head down, and was going to begin again, it was very provoking to find that the hedgehog had unrolled itself, and was in the act of crawling away: besides all this, there was generally a ridge or furrow in the way wherever she wanted to send the hedgehog to, and, as the doubled-up soldiers were always getting up and walking off to other parts of the ground, Alice soon came to the conclusion that it was a very difficult game indeed.

The players all played at once without waiting for turns, quarrelling all the while, and fighting for the hedgehogs; and in a very short time the Queen was in a furious passion, and went stamping about, and shouting

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the Queen was in a furious passion and went stamping about and shouting
quote.s: "Off with her head!"

div.p: about once in a minute.

quote.s: "what would become of me? They're dreadfully\nfond of beheading people here; the great wonder is, that there's any\none left alive!"

div.p: Alice began to feel very uneasy: to be sure, she had not as yet had any dispute with the Queen, but she knew that it might happen any minute, She was looking about for some way of escape, and wondering whether she could get away without being seen, when she noticed a curious appearance in the air: it puzzled her very much at first, but, after watching it a minute or two, she made it out to be a grin, and she said to herself

quote.s: "It's the Cheshire Cat: now I shall have somebody to talk\nto."
"How are you getting on?"

div.p: said the Cat, as soon as there was mouth enough for it to speak with.
Alice waited till the eyes appeared, and then nodded.

quote.s: "till its ears have come, or at least one\nof them."

div.p: In another minute the whole head appeared, and then Alice put down her flamingo, and began an account of the game, feeling very glad she had someone to listen to her. The Cat seemed to think that there was enough of it now in sight, and no more of it appeared.

quote.s:
"and they all quarrel so dreadfully one can't hear
oneself speak--and they don't seem to have any rules in particular; at
least, if there are, nobody attends to them--and you've no idea how
confusing it is all the things being alive; for instance, there's the
arch I've got to go through next walking about at the other end of the
ground--and I should have croqueted the Queen's hedgehog just now, only
it ran away when it saw mine coming!"
"How do you like the Queen?"

div.p: said the Cat in a low voice.

quote.s: "she's so extremely--"
"--likely to win, that it's hardly worth while finishing the game."

div.p: Just then she noticed that the Queen was close behind her, listening: so she went on, The Queen smiled and passed on.

quote.s: "Who are you talking to?"

div.p: said the King, going up to Alice, and looking at the Cat's head with great curiosity.

quote.s: "allow me to\nintroduce it."
"however, it may\nkiss my hand if it likes."
"I'd rather not,"

div.p: the Cat remarked.

quote.s: "and don't look at me like\nthat!"

div.p: He got behind Alice as he spoke.

quote.s: "I've read that in some book,\nbut I don't remember where."
"Well, it must be removed,"

div.p: said the King very decidedly, and he called the Queen, who was passing at the moment,

quote.s: "My dear! I wish you would\nhave this cat removed!"

div.p: The Queen had only one way of settling all difficulties, great or small.

quote.s: "Off with his head!"

div.p: she said, without even looking round.

quote.s: "I'll fetch the executioner myself,"

div.p: said the King eagerly, and he hurried off.

Alice thought she might as well go back, and see how the game was going on, as she heard the Queen's voice in the distance, screaming with passion. She had already heard her sentence three of the players to be executed for having missed their turns, and she did not like the look of things at all, as the game was in such confusion that she never knew whether it was her turn or not. So she went in search of her hedgehog.

The hedgehog was engaged in a fight with another hedgehog, which seemed to Alice an excellent opportunity for croqueting one of them with the other: the only difficulty was, that her flamingo was gone across to the other side of the garden, where Alice could see it trying in a helpless sort of way to fly up into a tree.
By the time she had caught the flamingo and brought it back, the fight was over, and both the hedgehogs were out of sight:

quote.s: "as all the arches are gone from this side\nof the ground."

div.p: So she tucked it away under her arm, that it might not escape again, and went back for a little more conversation with her friend.

When she got back to the Cheshire Cat, she was surprised to find quite a large crowd collected round it: there was a dispute going on between the executioner, the King, and the Queen, who were all talking at once, while all the rest were quite silent, and looked very uncomfortable.

The moment Alice appeared, she was appealed to by all three to settle the question, and they repeated their arguments to her, though, as they all spoke at once, she found it very hard indeed to make out exactly what they said.

The executioner's argument was, that you couldn't cut off a head unless there was a body to cut it off from: that he had never had to do such a thing before, and he wasn't going to begin at _his_ time of life.
The King's argument was, that anything that had a head could be beheaded, and that you weren't to talk nonsense.

The Queen's argument was, that if something wasn't done about it in less than no time she'd have everybody executed, all round. (It was this last remark that had made the whole party look so grave and anxious.)
Alice could think of nothing else to say but

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Alice could think of nothing else to say
quote.s: "It belongs to the\nDuchess: you'd better ask her about it."

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the Queen said to the executioner
quote.s: "fetch her here."

div.p: And the executioner went off like an arrow.

The Cat's head began fading away the moment he was gone, and, by the time he had come back with the Duchess, it had entirely disappeared; so the King and the executioner ran wildly up and down looking for it, while the rest of the party went back to the game.
div.head: CHAPTER IX.
div.p: The Mock Turtle's Story

quote.s: "You can't think how glad I am to see you again, you dear old thing!"

div.p: said the Duchess, as she tucked her arm affectionately into Alice's, and they walked off together.
Alice was very glad to find her in such a pleasant temper, and thought to herself that perhaps it was only the pepper that had made her so savage when they met in the kitchen.

quote.s:
"and vinegar that makes them sour--and camomile that makes
them bitter--and--and barley-sugar and such things that make children
sweet-tempered. I only wish people knew that: then they wouldn't be
so stingy about it, you know--"

div.p: She had quite forgotten the Duchess by this time, and was a little startled when she heard her voice close to her ear.

quote.s:
"You're thinking
about something, my dear, and that makes you forget to talk. I can't
tell you just now what the moral of that is, but I shall remember it in
a bit."
"Perhaps it hasn't one,"

div.p: Alice ventured to remark.

quote.s: "Everything's got a moral, if only\nyou can find it."

div.p: And she squeezed herself up closer to Alice's side as she spoke.

Alice did not much like keeping so close to her: first, because the Duchess was _very_ ugly; and secondly, because she was exactly the right height to rest her chin upon Alice's shoulder, and it was an uncomfortably sharp chin. However, she did not like to be rude, so she bore it as well as she could.

quote.s: "The game's going on rather better now,"

div.p: she said, by way of keeping up the conversation a little.

quote.s: "and the moral of that is--'Oh, 'tis love,\n'tis love, that makes the world go round!'"
"that it's done by everybody minding\ntheir own business!"
"and the moral of\nthat is--'Take care of the sense, and the sounds will take care of\nthemselves.'"
"How fond she is of finding morals in things!"

div.p: Alice thought to herself.

quote.s: "the reason is, that I'm doubtful about\nthe temper of your flamingo. Shall I try the experiment?"
"He might bite,"

div.p: Alice cautiously replied, not feeling at all anxious to have the experiment tried.

quote.s: "flamingoes and mustard both bite. And\nthe moral of that is--'Birds of a feather flock together.'"
"Only mustard isn't a bird,"

div.p: Alice remarked.

quote.s: "what a clear way you have of\nputting things!"
"It's a mineral, I think,"

div.p: said Alice.

quote.s: "there's a large mustard-mine near here.\nAnd the moral of that is--'The more there is of mine, the less there is\nof yours.'"
"it's a vegetable. It doesn't look like one, but it is."

"and the moral of that
is--'Be what you would seem to be'--or if you'd like it put more
simply--'Never imagine yourself not to be otherwise than what it might
appear to others that what you were or might have been was not
otherwise than what you had been would have appeared to them to be
otherwise.'"
"if I had it written down: but I can't quite follow it as you say it."
"That's nothing to what I could say if I chose,"

div.p: the Duchess replied, in a pleased tone.

quote.s: "Pray don't trouble yourself to say it any longer than that,"

div.p: said Alice.

quote.s: "I make you a present\nof everything I've said as yet."
"I'm glad they don't give\nbirthday presents like that!"

div.p: But she did not venture to say it out loud.

quote.s: "Thinking again?"

div.p: the Duchess asked, with another dig of her sharp little chin.

quote.s: "I've a right to think,"

div.p: said Alice sharply, for she was beginning to feel a little worried.

quote.s: "as pigs have to fly; and\nthe m--"

div.p: But here, to Alice's great surprise, the Duchess's voice died away, even in the middle of her favourite word 'moral,' and the arm that was linked into hers began to tremble. Alice looked up, and there stood the Queen in front of them, with her arms folded, frowning like a thunderstorm.

quote.s: "A fine day, your Majesty!"

div.p: the Duchess began in a low, weak voice.

quote.s: "either you or your head must be off, and that in\nabout half no time! Take your choice!"

div.p: The Duchess took her choice, and was gone in a moment.

quote.s: "Let's go on with the game,"

div.p: the Queen said to Alice; and Alice was too much frightened to say a word, but slowly followed her back to the croquet-ground.

The other guests had taken advantage of the Queen's absence, and were resting in the shade: however, the moment they saw her, they hurried back to the game, the Queen merely remarking that a moment's delay would cost them their lives.
All the time they were playing the Queen never left off quarrelling with the other players, and shouting

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the Queen never left off quarrelling with the other players and shouting
quote.s: "Off with\nher head!"

div.p: Those whom she sentenced were taken into custody by the soldiers, who of course had to leave off being arches to do this, so that by the end of half an hour or so there were no arches left, and all the players, except the King, the Queen, and Alice, were in custody and under sentence of execution.
Then the Queen left off, quite out of breath, and said to Alice,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the Queen left off quite out of breath and said to Alice
quote.s: "Have\nyou seen the Mock Turtle yet?"
"I don't even know what a Mock Turtle is."
"It's the thing Mock Turtle Soup is made from,"

div.p: said the Queen.

quote.s: "I never saw one, or heard of one,"

div.p: said Alice.

quote.s: "and he shall tell you his history,"

div.p: As they walked off together, Alice heard the King say in a low voice, to the company generally,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the King say in a low voice to the company
quote.s: "You are all pardoned."
"Come, that's a\ngood thing!"

div.p: she said to herself, for she had felt quite unhappy at the number of executions the Queen had ordered.
They very soon came upon a Gryphon, lying fast asleep in the sun. (If you don't know what a Gryphon is, look at the picture.)

quote.s: "and take this young lady to see the Mock\nTurtle, and to hear his history. I must go back and see after some\nexecutions I have ordered;"

div.p: and she walked off, leaving Alice alone with the Gryphon. Alice did not quite like the look of the creature, but on the whole she thought it would be quite as safe to stay with it as to go after that savage Queen: so she waited.
The Gryphon sat up and rubbed its eyes: then it watched the Queen till she was out of sight: then it chuckled.

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: said the Gryphon half to itself half to Alice
quote.s: "What fun!"

div.p: said the Gryphon, half to itself, half to Alice.

quote.s: "What is the fun?"

div.p: said Alice.

quote.s: "It's all her fancy, that: they never\nexecutes nobody, you know. Come on!"
"I never was so ordered about in all my life, never!"

div.p: They had not gone far before they saw the Mock Turtle in the distance, sitting sad and lonely on a little ledge of rock, and, as they came nearer, Alice could hear him sighing as if his heart would break. She pitied him deeply.

quote.s: "What is his sorrow?"

div.p: she asked the Gryphon, and the Gryphon answered, very nearly in the same words as before,

quote.s: "It's all\nhis fancy, that: he hasn't got no sorrow, you know. Come on!"

div.p: So they went up to the Mock Turtle, who looked at them with large eyes full of tears, but said nothing.

quote.s: "she wants for to know your\nhistory, she do."
"sit\ndown, both of you, and don't speak a word till I've finished."

div.p: So they sat down, and nobody spoke for some minutes. Alice thought to herself,

quote.s: "I don't see how he can ever finish, if he doesn't begin."

div.p: But she waited patiently.

quote.s: "I was a real\nTurtle."

div.p: These words were followed by a very long silence, broken only by an occasional exclamation of

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: broken only by an occasional exclamation of Hjckrrh from the Gryphon
quote.s: "Hjckrrh!"

div.p: from the Gryphon, and the constant heavy sobbing of the Mock Turtle. Alice was very nearly getting up and saying, "Thank you, sir, for your interesting story," but she could not help thinking there _must_ be more to come, so she sat still and said nothing.

quote.s: "we went to school in the\nsea. The master was an old Turtle--we used to call him Tortoise--"
"Why did you call him Tortoise, if he wasn't one?"

div.p: Alice asked.

quote.s: "really you are very dull!"
"You ought to be ashamed of yourself for asking such a simple\nquestion,"

div.p: added the Gryphon; and then they both sat silent and looked at poor Alice, who felt ready to sink into the earth. At last the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the Gryphon said to the Mock Turtle
quote.s: "Drive on, old fellow! Don't be all\nday about it!"

div.p: and he went on in these words:

quote.s: "Yes, we went to school in the sea, though you mayn't believe it--"
"I never said I didn't!"

div.p: interrupted Alice.

quote.s: "You did,"

div.p: said the Mock Turtle.

quote.s: "Hold your tongue!"

div.p: added the Gryphon, before Alice could speak again. The Mock Turtle went on.

quote.s: "We had the best of educations--in fact, we went to school every day--"
"you needn't be so\nproud as all that."
"With extras?"

div.p: asked the Mock Turtle a little anxiously.

quote.s: "we learned French and music."
"And washing?"

div.p: said the Mock Turtle.

quote.s: "Certainly not!"

div.p: said Alice indignantly.

quote.s: "Now at ours they had at the end of the bill,\n'French, music, and washing--extra.'"
"living at the bottom\nof the sea."
"I\nonly took the regular course."
"What was that?"

div.p: inquired Alice.

quote.s: "and then the different branches of Arithmetic--Ambition,\nDistraction, Uglification, and Derision."
"What is it?"

div.p: The Gryphon lifted up both its paws in surprise.

quote.s: "You know what to beautify is, I suppose?"
"it means--to--make--anything--prettier."
"if you don't know what to uglify\nis, you are a simpleton."

div.p: Alice did not feel encouraged to ask any more questions about it, so she turned to the Mock Turtle, and said

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: she turned to the Mock Turtle and said
quote.s: "What else had you to learn?"

"--Mystery, ancient and modern, with
Seaography: then Drawling--the Drawling-master was an old conger-eel,
that used to come once a week: he taught us Drawling, Stretching, and
Fainting in Coils."
"What was that like?"

div.p: said Alice.

quote.s: "I'm too\nstiff. And the Gryphon never learnt it."
"I went to the Classics master,\nthough. He was an old crab, he was."
"he taught\nLaughing and Grief, they used to say."
"So he did, so he did,"

div.p: said the Gryphon, sighing in his turn; and both creatures hid their faces in their paws.

quote.s: "And how many hours a day did you do lessons?"

div.p: said Alice, in a hurry to change the subject.

quote.s: "nine the next, and so\non."
"What a curious plan!"

div.p: exclaimed Alice.

quote.s: "because they lessen from day to day."

div.p: This was quite a new idea to Alice, and she thought it over a little before she made her next remark.

quote.s: "Then the eleventh day must have been\na holiday?"
"Of course it was,"

div.p: said the Mock Turtle.

quote.s: "And how did you manage on the twelfth?"

div.p: Alice went on eagerly.

quote.s: "tell her something about the games now."

div.head: CHAPTER X.
div.p: The Lobster Quadrille
The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and drew the back of one flapper across his eyes. He looked at Alice, and tried to speak, but for a minute or two sobs choked his voice.

quote.s: "Same as if he had a bone in his throat,"

div.p: said the Gryphon: and it set to work shaking him and punching him in the back. At last the Mock Turtle recovered his voice, and, with tears running down his cheeks, he went on again:--

quote.s: "You may not have lived much under the sea--"
"I haven't,"

div.p: said Alice)--

quote.s: "and perhaps you were never even introduced to a lobster--"

div.p: (Alice began to say

quote.s: "I once tasted--"

div.p: but checked herself hastily, and said

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: Alice began to say I once tasted but checked herself hastily and said
quote.s: "No, never"
"--so you can have no idea what a delightful thing a\nLobster Quadrille is!"
"What sort of a dance is it?"
"you first form into a line along the\nsea-shore--"
"Seals, turtles, salmon, and so on;\nthen, when you've cleared all the jelly-fish out of the way--"
"That generally takes some time,"

div.p: interrupted the Gryphon.

quote.s: "--you advance twice--"
"Each with a lobster as a partner!"

div.p: cried the Gryphon.

quote.s: "advance twice, set to partners--"
"--change lobsters, and retire in same order,"

div.p: continued the Gryphon.

quote.s: "you throw the--"
"The lobsters!"

div.p: shouted the Gryphon, with a bound into the air.

quote.s: "--as far out to sea as you can--"
"Swim after them!"

div.p: screamed the Gryphon.

quote.s: "Turn a somersault in the sea!"

div.p: cried the Mock Turtle, capering wildly about.

quote.s: "Change lobsters again!"

div.p: yelled the Gryphon at the top of its voice.

quote.s: "Back to land again, and that's all the first figure,"

div.p: said the Mock Turtle, suddenly dropping his voice; and the two creatures, who had been jumping about like mad things all this time, sat down again very sadly and quietly, and looked at Alice.

quote.s: "It must be a very pretty dance,"

div.p: said Alice timidly.

quote.s: "Would you like to see a little of it?"

div.p: said the Mock Turtle.

quote.s: "Very much indeed,"

div.p: said Alice.

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: said the Mock Turtle to the Gryphon
quote.s: "We can do without lobsters, you know. Which shall sing?"
"I've forgotten the words."

div.p: So they began solemnly dancing round and round Alice, every now and then treading on her toes when they passed too close, and waving their forepaws to mark the time, while the Mock Turtle sang this, very slowly and sadly:--

Will you walk a little faster?" said a whiting to a snail. There's a porpoise close behind us, and he's treading on my tail. See how eagerly the lobsters and the turtles all advance! They are waiting on the shingle--will you come and join the dance? Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, will you join the dance? Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, won't you join the dance?

You can really have no notion how delightful it will be When they take us up and throw us, with the lobsters, out to sea! But the snail replied "Too far, too far!" and gave a look askance-- Said he thanked the whiting kindly, but he would not join the dance. Would not, could not, would not, could not, would not join the dance. Would not, could not, would not, could not, could not join the dance.

What matters it how far we go?" his scaly friend replied. There is another shore, you know, upon the other side. The further off from England the nearer is to France-- Then turn not pale, beloved snail, but come and join the dance. Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, will you join the dance? Will you, won't you, will you, won't you, won't you join the dance?

quote.s: "and I do so like that\ncurious song about the whiting!"
"they--you've seen them,\nof course?"
"I've often seen them at dinn--"

div.p: she checked herself hastily.

quote.s: "but if you've\nseen them so often, of course you know what they're like."
"They have their tails in\ntheir mouths--and they're all over crumbs."
"crumbs would\nall wash off in the sea. But they have their tails in their mouths;\nand the reason is--"

div.p: here the Mock Turtle yawned and shut his eyes.--

quote.s: "Tell her about the reason and all that,"

div.p: he said to the Gryphon.

quote.s:
"that they would go with the
lobsters to the dance. So they got thrown out to sea. So they had to
fall a long way. So they got their tails fast in their mouths. So they
couldn't get them out again. That's all."
"it's very interesting. I never knew so much\nabout a whiting before."
"Do you\nknow why it's called a whiting?"
"Why?"
"It does the boots and shoes,"

div.p: the Gryphon replied very solemnly.
Alice was thoroughly puzzled.

quote.s: "Does the boots and shoes!"

div.p: she repeated in a wondering tone.

quote.s: "I mean, what\nmakes them so shiny?"

div.p: Alice looked down at them, and considered a little before she gave her answer.

quote.s: "They're done with blacking, I believe."
"are done with a whiting. Now you know."
"And what are they made of?"

div.p: Alice asked in a tone of great curiosity.

quote.s: "any shrimp could have told you that."
"I'd have said to the porpoise, 'Keep back,\nplease: we don't want you with us!'"
"no\nwise fish would go anywhere without a porpoise."
"Wouldn't it really?"

div.p: said Alice in a tone of great surprise.

quote.s: "why, if a fish came to me,\nand told me he was going a journey, I should say 'With what porpoise?'"
"Don't you mean 'purpose'?"

div.p: said Alice.

quote.s: "I mean what I say,"

div.p: the Mock Turtle replied in an offended tone. And the Gryphon added

quote.s: "Come, let's hear some of your adventures."
"but it's no use going back to yesterday,\nbecause I was a different person then."
"Explain all that,"

div.p: said the Mock Turtle.

quote.s: "explanations take such a dreadful time."

div.p: So Alice began telling them her adventures from the time when she first saw the White Rabbit. She was a little nervous about it just at first, the two creatures got so close to her, one on each side, and opened their eyes and mouths so _very_ wide, but she gained courage as she went on. Her listeners were perfectly quiet till she got to the part about her repeating "_You are old, Father William_," to the Caterpillar, and the words all coming different, and then the Mock Turtle drew a long breath, and said

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the Mock Turtle drew a long breath and said
quote.s: "That's very curious."
"It's all about as curious as it can be,"

div.p: said the Gryphon.

quote.s: "I\nshould like to hear her try and repeat something now. Tell her to\nbegin."

div.p: He looked at the Gryphon as if he thought it had some kind of authority over Alice.

quote.s: "Stand up and repeat ''Tis the voice of the sluggard,'"

div.p: said the Gryphon.

quote.s: "I might as well be at school at once."

div.p: However, she got up, and began to repeat it, but her head was so full of the Lobster Quadrille, that she hardly knew what she was saying, and the words came very queer indeed:--

'Tis the voice of the Lobster; I heard him declare, You have baked me too brown, I must sugar my hair. As a duck with its eyelids, so he with his nose Trims his belt and his buttons, and turns out his toes.

[later editions continued as follows When the sands are all dry, he is gay as a lark, And will talk in contemptuous tones of the Shark, But, when the tide rises and sharks are around, His voice has a timid and tremulous sound.]

quote.s: "That's different from what I used to say when I was a child,"

div.p: said the Gryphon.

quote.s: "I should like to have it explained,"

div.p: said the Mock Turtle.

quote.s: "Go on with the next\nverse."
"How could he turn\nthem out with his nose, you know?"
"It's the first position in dancing."

div.p: Alice said; but was dreadfully puzzled by the whole thing, and longed to change the subject.

quote.s: "it\nbegins"

div.p: '_I passed by his garden_.'
Alice did not dare to disobey, though she felt sure it would all come wrong, and she went on in a trembling voice:--
I passed by his garden, and marked, with one eye, How the Owl and the Panther were sharing a pie--

[later editions continued as follows The Panther took pie-crust, and gravy, and meat, While the Owl had the dish as its share of the treat. When the pie was all finished, the Owl, as a boon, Was kindly permitted to pocket the spoon: While the Panther received knife and fork with a growl, And concluded the banquet--]

quote.s: "if you don't explain it as you go on? It's by far the\nmost confusing thing I ever heard!"
"Yes, I think you'd better leave off,"

div.p: said the Gryphon: and Alice was only too glad to do so.

quote.s: "Or would you like the Mock Turtle to sing you a song?"
"Oh, a song, please, if the Mock Turtle would be so kind,"
"Hm! No accounting for tastes! Sing her 'Turtle Soup,' will you, old\nfellow?"

div.p: Alice replied, so eagerly that the Gryphon said, in a rather offended tone, The Mock Turtle sighed deeply, and began, in a voice sometimes choked with sobs, to sing this:--

Beautiful Soup, so rich and green, Waiting in a hot tureen! Who for such dainties would not stoop? Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup! Soup of the evening, beautiful Soup! Beau--ootiful Soo--oop! Beau--ootiful Soo--oop! Soo--oop of the e--e--evening, Beautiful, beautiful Soup!

Beautiful Soup! Who cares for fish, Game, or any other dish? Who would not give all else for two p ennyworth only of beautiful Soup? Pennyworth only of beautiful Soup? Beau--ootiful Soo--oop! Beau--ootiful Soo--oop! Soo--oop of the e--e--evening, Beautiful, beauti--FUL SOUP!

quote.s: "Come on!"

div.p: cried the Gryphon, and, taking Alice by the hand, it hurried off, without waiting for the end of the song.

quote.s: "What trial is it?"

div.p: Alice panted as she ran; but the Gryphon only answered

quote.s: "Come on!"

div.p: and ran the faster, while more and more faintly came, carried on the breeze that followed them, the melancholy words:--
Soo--oop of the e--e--evening, Beautiful, beautiful Soup!
div.head: CHAPTER XI.
div.p: Who Stole the Tarts?

The King and Queen of Hearts were seated on their throne when they arrived, with a great crowd assembled about them--all sorts of little birds and beasts, as well as the whole pack of cards: the Knave was standing before them, in chains, with a soldier on each side to guard him; and near the King was the White Rabbit, with a trumpet in one hand, and a scroll of parchment in the other. In the very middle of the court was a table, with a large dish of tarts upon it: they looked so good, that it made Alice quite hungry to look at them--

quote.s: "and hand round the refreshments!"

div.p: But there seemed to be no chance of this, so she began looking at everything about her, to pass away the time.
Alice had never been in a court of justice before, but she had read about them in books, and she was quite pleased to find that she knew the name of nearly everything there.

quote.s: "because of his great wig."

div.p: The judge, by the way, was the King; and as he wore his crown over the wig, (look at the frontispiece if you want to see how he did it,) he did not look at all comfortable, and it was certainly not becoming.

quote.s: "I suppose they are the jurors."

div.p: She said this last word two or three times over to herself, being rather proud of it: for she thought, and rightly too, that very few little girls of her age knew the meaning of it at all. However, "jury-men would have done just as well.
The twelve jurors were all writing very busily on slates.

quote.s: "They can't have anything\nto put down yet, before the trial's begun."
"for fear they should forget them before the end of the trial."
"Stupid things!"

div.p: Alice began in a loud, indignant voice, but she stopped hastily, for the White Rabbit cried out,

quote.s: "Silence in the\ncourt!"

div.p: and the King put on his spectacles and looked anxiously round, to make out who was talking.

Alice could see, as well as if she were looking over their shoulders, that all the jurors were writing down "stupid things!" on their slates, and she could even make out that one of them didn't know how to spell stupid," and that he had to ask his neighbour to tell him.

quote.s: "A nice\nmuddle their slates'll be in before the trial's over!"

div.p: thought Alice.

One of the jurors had a pencil that squeaked. This of course, Alice could _not_ stand, and she went round the court and got behind him, and very soon found an opportunity of taking it away. She did it so quickly that the poor little juror (it was Bill, the Lizard) could not make out at all what had become of it; so, after hunting all about for it, he was obliged to write with one finger for the rest of the day; and this was of very little use, as it left no mark on the slate.

quote.s: "Herald, read the accusation!"

div.p: said the King.
On this the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and then unrolled the parchment scroll, and read as follows:--
The Queen of Hearts, she made some tarts, All on a summer day: The Knave of Hearts, he stole those tarts, And took them quite away!

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the King said to the jury
quote.s: "Consider your verdict,"

div.p: the King said to the jury.

quote.s: "There's a great\ndeal to come before that!"
"Call the first witness,"

div.p: said the King; and the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet, and called out,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the White Rabbit blew three blasts on the trumpet and called out
quote.s: "First witness!"

div.p: The first witness was the Hatter. He came in with a teacup in one hand and a piece of bread-and-butter in the other.

quote.s: "for bringing these in: but I hadn't quite finished\nmy tea when I was sent for."
"When did you begin?"

div.p: The Hatter looked at the March Hare, who had followed him into the court, arm-in-arm with the Dormouse.

quote.s: "Fourteenth of March, I think it\nwas,"

div.p: he said.

quote.s: "Fifteenth,"

div.p: said the March Hare.

quote.s: "Sixteenth,"

div.p: added the Dormouse.

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the King said to the jury
quote.s: "Write that down,"

div.p: the King said to the jury, and the jury eagerly wrote down all three dates on their slates, and then added them up, and reduced the answer to shillings and pence.

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the King said to the Hatter
quote.s: "Take off your hat,"

div.p: the King said to the Hatter.

quote.s: "It isn't mine,"

div.p: said the Hatter.

quote.s: "Stolen!"

div.p: the King exclaimed, turning to the jury, who instantly made a memorandum of the fact.

quote.s: "I've none\nof my own. I'm a hatter."

div.p: Here the Queen put on her spectacles, and began staring at the Hatter, who turned pale and fidgeted.

quote.s: "and don't be nervous, or I'll\nhave you executed on the spot."

div.p: This did not seem to encourage the witness at all: he kept shifting from one foot to the other, looking uneasily at the Queen, and in his confusion he bit a large piece out of his teacup instead of the bread-and-butter.

Just at this moment Alice felt a very curious sensation, which puzzled her a good deal until she made out what it was: she was beginning to grow larger again, and she thought at first she would get up and leave the court; but on second thoughts she decided to remain where she was as long as there was room for her.

quote.s: "I can hardly breathe."
"I'm growing."
"You've no right to grow here,"

div.p: said the Dormouse.

quote.s: "you know you're growing\ntoo."
"not in\nthat ridiculous fashion."

div.p: And he got up very sulkily and crossed over to the other side of the court.
All this time the Queen had never left off staring at the Hatter, and, just as the Dormouse crossed the court, she said to one of the officers of the court,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: she said to one of the officers of the court
quote.s: "Bring me the list of the singers in the last concert!"

div.p: on which the wretched Hatter trembled so, that he shook both his shoes off.

quote.s: "or I'll have you\nexecuted, whether you're nervous or not."
"--and I hadn't begun my tea--not above a week or so--and what with the\nbread-and-butter getting so thin--and the twinkling of the tea--"
"The twinkling of the what?"

div.p: said the King.

quote.s: "It began with the tea,"

div.p: the Hatter replied.

quote.s: "Do you\ntake me for a dunce? Go on!"
"and most things twinkled after\nthat--only the March Hare said--"
"I didn't!"

div.p: the March Hare interrupted in a great hurry.

quote.s: "You did!"

div.p: said the Hatter.

quote.s: "I deny it!"

div.p: said the March Hare.

quote.s: "leave out that part."
"Well, at any rate, the Dormouse said--"

div.p: the Hatter went on, looking anxiously round to see if he would deny it too: but the Dormouse denied nothing, being fast asleep.

quote.s: "I cut some more bread-and-butter--"

div.p: But what did the Dormouse say?" one of the jury asked.

quote.s: "That I can't remember,"

div.p: said the Hatter.

quote.s: "or I'll have you executed."

div.p: The miserable Hatter dropped his teacup and bread-and-butter, and went down on one knee.

quote.s: "I'm a poor man, your Majesty,"

div.p: he began.

quote.s: "You're a very poor speaker,"

div.p: said the King.

Here one of the guinea-pigs cheered, and was immediately suppressed by the officers of the court. (As that is rather a hard word, I will just explain to you how it was done. They had a large canvas bag, which tied up at the mouth with strings: into this they slipped the guinea-pig, head first, and then sat upon it.)

quote.s: "and I never understood what it meant till now."
"If that's all you know about it, you may stand down,"

div.p: continued the King.

quote.s: "I'm on the floor, as it is."
"Then you may sit down,"

div.p: the King replied.
Here the other guinea-pig cheered, and was suppressed.

quote.s: "Now we shall get\non better."
"I'd rather finish my tea,"

div.p: said the Hatter, with an anxious look at the Queen, who was reading the list of singers.

quote.s: "You may go,"

div.p: said the King, and the Hatter hurriedly left the court, without even waiting to put his shoes on.

quote.s: "--and just take his head off outside,"

div.p: the Queen added to one of the officers: but the Hatter was out of sight before the officer could get to the door.

quote.s: "Call the next witness!"

div.p: said the King.

The next witness was the Duchess's cook. She carried the pepper-box in her hand, and Alice guessed who it was, even before she got into the court, by the way the people near the door began sneezing all at once.

quote.s: "Give your evidence,"

div.p: said the King.

quote.s: "Shan't,"

div.p: said the cook.

quote.s: "Your Majesty must cross-examine this witness."
"What are tarts made of?"
"Pepper, mostly,"

div.p: The King looked anxiously at the White Rabbit, who said in a low voice, said the cook.

quote.s: "Treacle,"

div.p: said a sleepy voice behind her.

quote.s: "Behead that Dormouse!\nTurn that Dormouse out of court! Suppress him! Pinch him! Off with his\nwhiskers!"

div.p: For some minutes the whole court was in confusion, getting the Dormouse turned out, and, by the time they had settled down again, the cook had disappeared.

quote.s: "Call the\nnext witness."

div.p: And he added in an undertone to the Queen,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: he added in an undertone to the Queen
quote.s: "Really, my\ndear, you must cross-examine the next witness. It quite makes my\nforehead ache!"

div.p: Alice watched the White Rabbit as he fumbled over the list, feeling very curious to see what the next witness would be like,

quote.s: "--for they\nhaven't got much evidence yet,"

div.p: she said to herself. Imagine her surprise, when the White Rabbit read out, at the top of his shrill little voice, the name

quote.s: "Alice!"

div.head: CHAPTER XII.
div.p: Alice's Evidence

quote.s: "Here!"

div.p: cried Alice, quite forgetting in the flurry of the moment how large she had grown in the last few minutes, and she jumped up in such a hurry that she tipped over the jury-box with the edge of her skirt, upsetting all the jurymen on to the heads of the crowd below, and there they lay sprawling about, reminding her very much of a globe of goldfish she had accidentally upset the week before.

quote.s: "Oh, I beg your pardon!"

div.p: she exclaimed in a tone of great dismay, and began picking them up again as quickly as she could, for the accident of the goldfish kept running in her head, and she had a vague sort of idea that they must be collected at once and put back into the jury-box, or they would die.

quote.s: "until\nall the jurymen are back in their proper places--all,"

div.p: he repeated with great emphasis, looking hard at Alice as he said so.

Alice looked at the jury-box, and saw that, in her haste, she had put the Lizard in head downwards, and the poor little thing was waving its tail about in a melancholy way, being quite unable to move. She soon got it out again, and put it right;

quote.s: "I should think it would be quite as much use in the\ntrial one way up as the other."

div.p: As soon as the jury had a little recovered from the shock of being upset, and their slates and pencils had been found and handed back to them, they set to work very diligently to write out a history of the accident, all except the Lizard, who seemed too much overcome to do anything but sit with its mouth open, gazing up into the roof of the court.

quote.s: "What do you know about this business?"

div.p: the King said to Alice.

quote.s: "Nothing,"

div.p: said Alice.

quote.s: "Nothing whatever?"

div.p: persisted the King.

quote.s: "Nothing whatever,"

div.p: said Alice.

quote.s: "That's very important,"

div.p: the King said, turning to the jury. They were just beginning to write this down on their slates, when the White Rabbit interrupted:

quote.s: "Unimportant, your Majesty means, of course,"

div.p: he said in a very respectful tone, but frowning and making faces at him as he spoke.

quote.s: "Unimportant, of course, I meant,"

div.p: the King hastily said, and went on to himself in an undertone,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the King hastily said and went on to himself
quote.s: "important--unimportant--unimportant--important--"

div.p: as if he were trying which word sounded best.

quote.s: "but it doesn't matter a bit,"

div.p: Some of the jury wrote it down "important," and some "unimportant. Alice could see this, as she was near enough to look over their slates; she thought to herself.
At this moment the King, who had been for some time busily writing in his note-book, cackled out

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: the King who had been for some time busily writing in his notebook cackled out
quote.s: "Silence!"

div.p: and read out from his book, "Rule Forty-two. _All persons more than a mile high to leave the court_.
Everybody looked at Alice.

quote.s: "I'm not a mile high,"

div.p: said Alice.

quote.s: "You are,"

div.p: said the King.

quote.s: "Nearly two miles high,"

div.p: added the Queen.

quote.s: "besides, that's not a\nregular rule: you invented it just now."
"It's the oldest rule in the book,"

div.p: said the King.

quote.s: "Then it ought to be Number One,"

div.p: said Alice.
The King turned pale, and shut his note-book hastily.

quote.s: "Consider your\nverdict,"

div.p: he said to the jury, in a low, trembling voice.

quote.s: "this paper has just been\npicked up."
"What's in it?"

div.p: said the Queen.

quote.s: "but it seems to be a\nletter, written by the prisoner to--to somebody."
"unless it was written to\nnobody, which isn't usual, you know."

div.p: Who is it directed to?" said one of the jurymen.

quote.s: "and that's the queerest\nthing about it."

div.p: (The jury all looked puzzled.)

quote.s: "He must have imitated somebody else's hand,"

div.p: said the King. (The jury all brightened up again.)

quote.s: "I didn't write it, and they\ncan't prove I did: there's no name signed at the end."
"that only makes the matter\nworse. You must have meant some mischief, or else you'd have signed\nyour name like an honest man."

div.p: There was a general clapping of hands at this: it was the first really clever thing the King had said that day.

quote.s: "That proves his guilt,"

div.p: said the Queen.

quote.s: "Why, you don't even know\nwhat they're about!"
"Read them,"

div.p: said the King.
The White Rabbit put on his spectacles.

quote.s: "Where shall I begin, please\nyour Majesty?"

div.p: he asked.

quote.s: "and go on till you\ncome to the end: then stop."

div.p: These were the verses the White Rabbit read:--
They told me you had been to her, And mentioned me to him: She gave me a good character, But said I could not swim.
He sent them word I had not gone (We know it to be true): If she should push the matter on, What would become of you?
I gave her one, they gave him two, You gave us three or more; They all returned from him to you, Though they were mine before.
If I or she should chance to be Involved in this affair, He trusts to you to set them free, Exactly as we were.
My notion was that you had been (Before she had this fit) An obstacle that came between Him, and ourselves, and it.
Don't let him know she liked them best, For this must ever be A secret, kept from all the rest, Between yourself and me.

quote.s: "so now let the jury--"
"I'll give him sixpence. I don't believe there's\nan atom of meaning in it."

div.p: The jury all wrote down on their slates, "_She_ doesn't believe there's an atom of meaning in it," but none of them attempted to explain the paper.

quote.s: "you can't swim, can you?"

div.p: he added, turning to the Knave.
The Knave shook his head sadly.

quote.s: "Do I look like it?"

div.p: he said. (Which he certainly did _not_, being made entirely of cardboard.)

quote.s: "why, that must be what he\ndid with the tarts, you know--"
"But, it goes on"

div.p: '_they all returned from him to you_,'" said Alice.

quote.s: "Nothing can be clearer than that. Then\nagain--"

div.p: '_before she had this fit_--'

quote.s: "you never had fits, my dear, I\nthink?"

div.p: he said to the Queen.

quote.s: "Never!"

div.p: said the Queen furiously, throwing an inkstand at the Lizard as she spoke. (The unfortunate little Bill had left off writing on his slate with one finger, as he found it made no mark; but he now hastily began again, using the ink, that was trickling down his face, as long as it lasted.)

quote.s: "Then the words don't fit you,"

div.p: said the King, looking round the court with a smile. There was a dead silence.

quote.s: "Let the jury consider their verdict,"

div.p: the King said, for about the twentieth time that day.

quote.s: "Sentence first--verdict afterwards."
"The idea of having the\nsentence first!"
"Hold your tongue!"

div.p: said the Queen, turning purple.

quote.s: "I won't!"

div.p: said Alice.

quote.s: "Off with her head!"

div.p: the Queen shouted at the top of her voice. Nobody moved.

quote.s: "You're nothing but a pack of cards!"

div.p: At this the whole pack rose up into the air, and came flying down upon her: she gave a little scream, half of fright and half of anger, and tried to beat them off, and found herself lying on the bank, with her head in the lap of her sister, who was gently brushing away some dead leaves that had fluttered down from the trees upon her face.

quote.s: "Why, what a long sleep you've\nhad!"
"Oh, I've had such a curious dream!"

div.p: said Alice, and she told her sister, as well as she could remember them, all these strange Adventures of hers that you have just been reading about; and when she had finished, her sister kissed her, and said,

quote.novel-dialogism:referringExpression: her sister kissed her and said
quote.s: "It was a curious\ndream, dear, certainly: but now run in to your tea; it's getting late."

div.p: So Alice got up and ran off, thinking while she ran, as well she might, what a wonderful dream it had been.

But her sister sat still just as she left her, leaning her head on her hand, watching the setting sun, and thinking of little Alice and all her wonderful Adventures, till she too began dreaming after a fashion, and this was her dream:--

First, she dreamed of little Alice herself, and once again the tiny hands were clasped upon her knee, and the bright eager eyes were looking up into hers--she could hear the very tones of her voice, and see that queer little toss of her head to keep back the wandering hair that would always get into her eyes--and still as she listened, or seemed to listen, the whole place around her became alive with the strange creatures of her little sister's dream.

The long grass rustled at her feet as the White Rabbit hurried by--the frightened Mouse splashed his way through the neighbouring pool--she could hear the rattle of the teacups as the March Hare and his friends shared their never-ending meal, and the shrill voice of the Queen ordering off her unfortunate guests to execution--once more the pig-baby was sneezing on the Duchess's knee, while plates and dishes crashed around it--once more the shriek of the Gryphon, the squeaking of the Lizard's slate-pencil, and the choking of the suppressed guinea-pigs, filled the air, mixed up with the distant sobs of the miserable Mock Turtle.

So she sat on, with closed eyes, and half believed herself in Wonderland, though she knew she had but to open them again, and all would change to dull reality--the grass would be only rustling in the wind, and the pool rippling to the waving of the reeds--the rattling teacups would change to tinkling sheep-bells, and the Queen's shrill cries to the voice of the shepherd boy--and the sneeze of the baby, the shriek of the Gryphon, and all the other queer noises, would change (she knew) to the confused clamour of the busy farm-yard--while the lowing of the cattle in the distance would take the place of the Mock Turtle's heavy sobs.

Lastly, she pictured to herself how this same little sister of hers would, in the after-time, be herself a grown woman; and how she would keep, through all her riper years, the simple and loving heart of her childhood: and how she would gather about her other little children, and make their eyes bright and eager with many a strange tale, perhaps even with the dream of Wonderland of long ago: and how she would feel with all their simple sorrows, and find a pleasure in all their simple joys, remembering her own child-life, and the happy summer days.
